REPORT OF THE AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS Thk State of Nebraska, Office of Aiditou of Public Accounts OLN, December 1, 1906. To His Excellency, /obn H. Mid, mor of the State of Nebraska »Dear Sir: In compliance with the Statutes relative to re >rts of this department, we take pleasure in transmitting to u our tirst V>iennial report. tTne following comprehensive statement- ompiled with eat care from the records of this office. We believe tl reful study of the tabular statements will iblic a clear understanding of all fiscal transactions of our ite government. fAt the close of the biennium, Nov. 30, 1904, the floating in - rest bearing debt of the state amounted to $2,258,401.92. At e close of the biennium Nov. 80, 1906, the floating int aring debt amounted to $ I. 1 . 1 1 . showing a decrease of til for the period. The special levy provided by the leldon bill has retired $i 16 of the debt, and the !l.4r> decrease came through the increased valuation and new operty listed. This has been brought about by the operation of the ! • ■nue Law. A large per cent of the County Treasure i port that under the present system over ninety nine per cent of the tax levied is collected. Statement No. 4 shows the total estimated income of the General Fund for the fiscal period commencing Apr. 1, 1907 and ending March 81, 1909 to be $2, ( .fJti,t574.O7. This estimate is based upon eighty five per cent of the probable lev i> and 1906, presuming that the uents and 1. thes> vill not diffi rially from the total assessment

6 the amount of the estimated income would be $4: ter than the foregoing estimate indicates; and in vie :act that practically ail of the t d, is collected, would make a total income of $3. Iie total assessed value of all property in the state for the • 1906, was $31 3,060, 301.02. and the levy for General Fund MM8 was four and one-half mills. A re valuation of te in ould show a marked in in value on this s of property over the year 1 '.♦<>•>. A comparison of per - .1 property assessments for the years 1 ( .H>4, 1 ( .HC> and 1906, healthy iacra— r the previous one, in - ting that is, under the direction of the State Hoard quali sessment, as they become aoqnaii ue Law and its workings, return truer ations and uncover more property each year. To the estimated income from the levies of 1807 and been added a conservative estimate of the income from back taxes and from miscellaneous soun by Statement ), making the total estimate of income for the General Fund!?. ed. E;ainst the estimated General Fund income of $"J, ( .^ > ti,Ci74.O7 requirements for the biennial period commencing 1, 1!K)7, and chargeable to the General Fund, amount- Ml tourth in Statement No. v been prepared by the heads of rtments and institutions and are on file with this depart ■ Th shows that estimated ex p< the biennium exceed the estimated receipts by s |>'.i.4f> ( .t.77 It will be necessary for the legislature to carry out the good business administration we have had heretofore, that tl nay be kept within the provisions of the law. new revenue act was required in order that the busi of tl might be conducted upon a sound financial I 3 new law has met the expectations of all, in the inert valuations returned, which enables the State Hoard of Kquali n and ent, without burdensome and • > provide for the need The with the co-operation c - and 1

7 E native boards, should be in a position to make appropria - s so as to keep the expenditures within the income of the ft. A summary of the insurance business of the state for the past biennium is incorporated herein and made a part of this report. Mr. John L. Pierce, Insurance Deputy, in his letter of ti ansmittal, which is made a part of the insurance report, fur - nishes a statement of the receipts incident to the department during the biennium, and makes recommendations with refer - ence to needed insurance legislation that are worthy of atten - tion. In connection with the Insurance Department, I wish especially to call your attention to the growth which is evi - denced by the increased receipts. The receipts for the bienni - um of 1903 and 1 ( .K>4 amounted to $133,901.00, and for 1006 and 1906, $21-J,1!K97, an increase of $78,297.97. An examination of the report of miscellaneous receipts of the different offices will show that this department collects nearly eighty per cent of all fees paid into the state treasury. Respectfully submitted, E. M. Searle, Jr., Auditor of Public Accounts.

REPORT OF THE Insurance Department OF THE STATE OF NEBRASKA FOR THE BIENNIUM DECEMBER 14, 1904, TO NOVEMBER 30, 190G JOHN L. PIERCE INSURANCE DEPUTY

REPORT Lincoln, December 1. HON. E. M. SEAKLE, Jr. Auditor of Public Accounts, Sir.— I have the honor to transmit herewith a detailed statement of the business transacted by the Insurance Department of the State of Ne hrafcka for the biennium commencing December 1, 1904, and closing No - vember 80,1908; also a summary of the business done by the various insur - ance companies transacting business in this state, taken from the sworn statements of the said companies filed with this department for the years and MX).-.. There has been paid to the State Treasurer the receipts incident to the business of the Insurance Department in the past biennium amounting to 17. Of this amount there was received for reciprocal taxes fur taxes on the gross premiums of foreign life, accident and t.urety companies fi •■>»>. IW'Xi. for fees *54 These receipts show a lerable increase above the normal over those of the preceding bien niiim. owing to the collection of reciprocal taxes which have been with - held from payment for two years. The validity of the Reciprocal Tax Law. which bad been 'juestioned by the fire insurance companies, in suit instituted for that purpose, was finally settled in the spring uf 19 the Supreme Court of the state, sustaining the law. In this connection it might be of interest to note the amount of insur- ance fees and taxes paid to the State Treasurer in the past ten yearn. wn,vm 4n ... 17,553 87 82,886 66 >900.. 47,569 32 901 38,186 48 902 4.5,321 14 1903. . 56,356 78 .904 77,548 28 [905 88,765 90 .906 123,433 07

340 LIFE INSURANCE Pny last biennial report, life insurance has held the attention of to a greater degree than has any other class of business, at on the part of some of the officers and directors of leading led to investigations and examinations l>y Insurance Depart Legislatures, also to a thorough probing by special committees from the directory of the companies involved. Although the examinations made, revealed an absolutely solvent condi - tion of the companies under fire, yet there were found instances of ex - travagance and mismanagement. Funds had )>een used for improper pur - poses and questionable methods were employed in the procuring and hand - ling of investments. The lack of mutuality in the mutual companies shown in the schemes employed to perj>etuate managements was also dis- Among those who have watched the developments referred to most closely, including the members of the various legislative committees and many supervising state officials, the majority seem to he convinced that tbe evils which have l«en disclosed, are chiefly due to what is known as the deferred dividend plan of life insurance contracts and to the immense volume of unassigned surplus which the companies have amassed under this form of insurance. Almost every report on the subject made by leg - inmittees and by supervising officials has unqualifiedly con - demned the deferred dividend plan. t However, it seems to me that the great evil lies in tbe fact that com - es issuing such policies have not been required to keep their accounts make their reports so as to show exactly how much of the so-called lus belongs to this class of policies, and to report the same as a liabil it being in fact a fund simply held in trust for tbe policy holder who ies his contract to maturity. A very large proportion of the insurance carried by the citizens of Nebraska is carried upon the deferred dividend plan, and I wish to urge that the interests of the holders of such contracts be protected by legisla - tion which shall compel tbe annual apportionment and accounting for this trust fund, and a showing of it not M a surplus but as a liability ; how - ever, if legislation upon ti is subject is effected, provision should be made allowing a company to retain a reasonable and equitable amount for a contingency reserve. As a result of tbe investigations which were made, some legislation lias already been enacted in a few States. New York, for instance, has effected sweeping changes in the law governing life insurance companies; more particularly in regard to the election of the directors of mutual companies, tbe prohibition of the issue of deferred dividend contracts, the limitation of new business, the limitation of agents commissions and the limitation of expenses. Time alone can determine as to the wisdom of these laws and especially those relating to the publication of lists of policy holders, the limitation of new usinexs and placing limits upon agents commissions.

341 §The majority of the Insurance Commissioners of the United - e felt the responsibility of the existing situation and have given care - and earnest thought to the questions of the hour. A conference of Governors. Attorneys General and Insurance C >ners was held in Chicago in February l!»i»i. about two- thirds of the states and territories being represented, to consult about taking definite towards uniformity in the insurance laws particularly as relating to life insurance. At this meeting resolutions were adopted lecommending the abolition of the deferred dividend system and calling for annual ac - counting of surplus, upholding the right of policy holders to tepresenta - tion. recommending greater publicity and declaring in favor of standard forms of policies. The conference appointed a committee of rift* > frame a uniform law tor the regulation of insurance. Nebraska I represented upon this committee. II meetings were held by the committee of fifteen and a - unt of till! iided con 5 and iife insurance men. in in accordance with the reso - ms of the Chicago Conference and in accordance with si i lie National Convention of Insurance Commissioners. la the th of November last the committee of fifteen complei - i and ing to life in- \ hich , will ibmitted for consideration to the m of the Union this winter. Tin d n> uimarized are as follow An act providing for standard ]>olicies and standard provisions. tAn annual appointment act which requires life ii er to i>ay annual dividends or credit the amoi. I to the ■ policy holders, the act limiting the amount of surplus which allowed to retain in their treasuries. An act prohibiting discrimination and rebating policy holders. act prohibiting corporations from acting of life insur - compani- tAn act regulating the election of directors of mutual life insu il prohibiting the publishing of estimate! ami illustrations « he terms of any policy or the benefits or ads thereby. An act prohibiting life insurance eomp. 'ii making any kind political contribution. An act forbidding insurance companies fro: ing won without the consent of tli of di- act prohibiting life insurance companies from lary in annually. An act regulating the investment of a life insurance company's funds.

342 An act defining the status of th la who solicit life insur.* An act prohibiting life insurance companies from issuing participat - ing and non-participating polici' An act regulating the disbursements of life insurance companies. An act regulating companies run on the life nt plan. An act regulating the retirement of the capital stock of life lnsii companies The San Francisco conflagration which occurred in April an event which deeply affected the fire insuring public. The soh of all the fire insu. upon the Pacific coast was severely tested. 1 a that more than a dozen - have had to reinsure their I wth other companies on ac - count of their inability their excessive liabilities occasioned by their losses in this fire. Among the companies so reinsuring are si that have done a very large business in Nebraska for many years, but the -uring compaiii tong and the insured amply protected. The attention of this department has been called in the p.i to quite a number of fires of incendiary origin, but where i bean difficult to bring the parties to justice. This difficulty has nient of a fire marshal! law, particu - larly in the states of Ohio and North Carolina where ineendian bave been reduced to a minimum by the efficiency of t).' itions made by the fire marshalls. tl believe it would be conducive to Ju insurance and so protect the insured if a fire marshall law I upon our statute books. I The question has been raised in connection with surety companies to the amount of surety Ixind that should be carried by any one com - ay. I believe it would he a wise plan and conduch :y to limit 1 liability a surety company may assume on any one risk. Bi such liability to one-tenth of the amount lus, and I would recommend the passage a similar law for tai » There are certain amendments to the insurance law that are H' ng of a co: il nature, and I would call your atl the following: Chapter 16, relating to domestic li luires the auditor to cause a brief abstract of the com]' to be publis! I one newspaper at the capital. For ike of uniformity with other laws and to make the requirement of alue this law should read, "To cause a brief abstract of such I together with his certificate that such company has complied with the law of the sta- kg to insurance, to be published in two i papers of general c q one of which newspapers is published at the d."

343 tm 5, Chapter 16, governing foreign legal reserve life insurance panics should be amended so as to provide for publishing brief ab - ets of annual statements the same as domestic companies; the sec - being silent as lo such publication. Chapter 16 should 1><' ling a new section providing for paid by all I life companies. At the present time BO law providing : k life insurance comp. from the provision found in the reciprocal section of tho law. Chapter 16, referring to the publishing of absti. annual statement of surety companies shoui I that the Bcate of authority my the published abstract; also the publication be made in tw of general circulation, : which is published at the S iltal. Iv companies, should be amended as to include fees for the company's certificate of authority and for the tificate of publication. The law governing accident and sic npaniea found in m i 164, chapter 4:!, should have a new section providing for fees to be by this class of companies. At nothing in th< ing to fe. Sect 4ii tire insurance companies requires a special deposit of $25,000 in some one of the United Stai> ories for the I'tnefit or security of the insured therein. This law inoperati 1 letter upon our ooks for iled. Section 78. Chapter 4:;, investment of fun is of mutual benefit associ - ations, provides that when a company deposits its - \<ith the Auditor of Si Uall furnish such corporation with a < under his seal of office of such deposit showing the purpose of the deposit, -howing the ;u iich corporation or asso - n at the date of the issuance of such certificate. 349 BANKERS UNION OF THE WORLD. t Early in 1904 this department, acting upon the report of an examina - and with the assistance of the Attorney General, commenced pro - ings to wind up the affairs of the Bankers Union of the World, a ?rnal beneficiary society with (headquarters at Omaha. tThis action was brought before the Supreme Court of the state, which, all questions of law, sustains i the department; but the Court further ided that if the irregularities and abuses complained of were corn Auditor should then license the sooi The officers of the Bankers I'nion of the World made promi Bt such abuses. Thereupon, a license was issued until March .u which time it was foun.l that the officers had not kept their promises and that conditions were no better than at the time the exam- OH referred to was made, whereupon license wa ■> again The ty then brought legal proceedings to compel the Auditor to re its license and was again sustained by the Supreme Court and li. was once more issued under the direction of the Court, extending to March 1st, 1906. This department refused to license the society for the following reasons: First — That Uw nts in regard to its Second — That its statements had been falsified in regard to ii hilities. I Third — That the department had been overwhelmed with chair id. deception and extortion on the part of the Bankers Union of the rid in the matter of adjustment and settlement of its policy claims. The society made no attempt to compel tho department to recede its i>osition; but instead, its supreme officers secretl d the ioni the juris iction of this department. The officers taking " tion have, with others, incorporated the Bankers Union of C'h Dg to transfer the membership of the old order to th. :.v.
